com.dautelle
Class JADE

java.lang.Object
  com.dautelle.JADE
public final class JADE
extends java.lang.Object

This class represents the JADE library; it contains the library initialize() method as well as a main(java.lang.String[]) method for versionning, self-tests, and performance analysis.

Initialization is mandatory for packages using the Unit class (e.g. physics and money). It ensures that the unit database is loaded and that predefined quantities are recognized. Initialization can be performed either at start-up (recommended):

     public static void main(String[] args) {
         com.dautelle.JADE.initialize();
         ... // Initializes other classes (e.g. custom quantity classes).
     }
or dynamically (class initialization). For example:
     class ClassUsingUnits {
         static {
             com.dautelle.JADE.initialize(); // No effect if library
                                             // already initialized.
         }
     }

Failure to initialize, results in IllegalStateException being thrown.

Version:
4.4, March 31, 2003
Author:
Jean-Marie Dautelle

Method Detail

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
The library main(java.lang.String[]) method. The archive jade.jar is auto-executable.
  • java -jar jade.jar to output version information.
  • java -jar jade.jar test to perform self-tests.
  • java -jar jade.jar perf for performance analysis.

Parameters:
args - the option arguments.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if a problem occurs.

initialize

public static void initialize()
Initializes library classes. This method has to be called at least once by the application (typically at start-up). It ensures that:
  1. The unit database is loaded (e.g. Unit.valueOf("ft") returns NonSI.FOOT).
  2. Predefined quantity sub-classes are mapped to their respective units (e.g. Quantity.valueOf(1, SI.METER) returns a Length instance).
  3. Class initialization is performed in a HeapContext. Static class members are allocated on the heap and can safely be referenced anywhere.
  4. Classes are initialized in the correct order. The initialization state is unvarying, regardless of library usages.
  5. Execution time is more predictable as class initialization has already been performed.

Note: It the library is extended (e.g. new quantity sub-classes), it is the responsibility of the application to ensure that the new classes are properly initialized as well.

verify

public static void verify()
Verifies that the library is in a correct state (initialized).

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the library has not been initialized.
See Also:
initialize()
